dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the registration hall three well-dressed y women -- stylish, black ROSE; cute, insipid HEATHER and pretty VIOLET -- spot a lonely-looking new student.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Look.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. I think so. Violet approaches the lithe, pretty but sad-looking LILY. VIOLET (CONT’D) Hello. Are you a new student?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Good -- we thought so. We’d like to help you.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Help me? What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four walk across the green, leafy quadrangle formed b the university’s handsome old brick buildings. INSERT TITLE: “The Quadrangle, Seven Oaks University”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: As a freshman, it can be very tough. You finally get to college, it’s supposed to be so great but, generally -- it’s not. University life can be pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: There are a lot of suicides.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, attempted ones.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m not actually a freshman. I'ma transfer student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... An “entering Sophomore?”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: So you were unhappy at your old school and are looking to recover here? Well, I think you will! Violet encourages her with a huge smile. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Would you welcome that? Would our help and guidance be something you’d appreciate, or would you rather sink or swim on your own? Either way’s fine, we’d still be friends.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, whichever you'd prefer.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes. Sure.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Great! Well, let’s start immediately. She gives Lily a very quick looking over. VIOLET (CONT’D) Clothes can be critical for confidence -- and an overall sense of well-being.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You don’t like my clothes?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It’s not about liking or not liking...

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What's it about?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How you look when you put them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right clothes don’t have to be expensive.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No, all you need are friends of about the same size. A grungy pack of male students approaches, inconsideratel hogging the path, obliging the girls to step aside. Sudde Rose looks like she’s smelled something foul; Violet gags

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Phew! Rose bends over, hyperventilating -- it’s a bit scary.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You didn’t notice that?!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, what?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Those guys! That smell! That awful acrid odor. Rose’s hyperventilating gets a little less. [Film full speech in both locations: ] VIOLET (CONT’D) Rose has a very sensitive nose.... INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 3 Rose lies in her bunk, a handkerchief to her nose.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: ..--Have you heard of “nasal shock syndrome?” Any harsh, acrid, or just “disgusting” odor sends Rose into nasal shock--

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (very nasally) This wasn’t true nasal shock. Had it been, I’d’ve lost consciousness entirely.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (smiles) Just from some b.o.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “Just some b.o.?!” Omigod, Lily, you must have a very high threshold for pain! That’1ll serve you well here at Seven Oaks!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Seven Oaks is notorious for it’s b.o. It was the last of the “Select Seven” to go co-ed. (looks around, combative) An atmosphere of male barbarism predominates -- but we’re going to change all that!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes! Lily heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’ve got to get to the housing department -- it seems they lost my rooming assignment.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That's terrible. You've no place to stay? Lily shakes her head, her eyes watering a little. VIOLET (CONT’D) They lost your housing assignment?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: How could they lose it?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Was it just mislaid?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, there were more acceptances than they anticipated and not enough rooms to go around. Violet exchanges quick looks with Rose and Heather.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why don’t you stay with us?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Considerable movement in front of the mirrors as the girl prepare for a night out.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You mustn’t think of this in the old fashioned sense of going to a party to “find someone” or “not find someone.” That’s not the dynamic we’re talking about.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What dynamic are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m glad you asked that. Our going to a party of this kind is more a form of... “youth outreach”--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: “Youth outreach.” It’s not just some moronic frat house social function--

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Though it will be that.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, but what we’ve got to keep in mind is -- these guys are very young, they’re “young people”-- Violet opens the door and goes halfway out, with one part comment. VIOLET (CONT’D) They're essentially immature, crying out for help and guidance. She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Though they don’t know that.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: No. They don’t, but we do.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But aren’t they the same age as we are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only numerically. Violet returns, carrying a beautiful dress.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m a lot fatter than you are but I think we could pin it.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigosh it’s beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Stunning. Lily puts the dress up to see how it looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: Saturday Evening “Youth Outreach”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possible POV shot of a wooden frat clubhouse from which p music and crowd spills. Girls could walk into POV, or we just see them heading that way.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Take Frank, my friend -- he’s not some cool, handsome, “studly” macho- type. No, not at all -- I can’t stand guys like that! He’s more of a sad-sack really, wouldn’t you say? Rose and Heather nod.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Definitely.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What’s a “sad-sack?”

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (forcefully) A loo-ser!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (to Violet) You like losers?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Very much so. Do you know what’s the major problem in contemporary social life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The tendency, very widespread, to always seek someone “cooler” than yourself -- it’s always a stretch, often a big stretch. Why not find someone who’s frankly inferior?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Someone like Frank.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. It’s more rewarding and in fact quite reassuring.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You mean, someone you can really help? Not just thinking of yourself?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes! That’s it. Precisely! But without the goody-goody implications -- our aspirations are pretty basic: Take a guy who hasn’t realized his full potential, or doesn’t even have much and then help him realize it -- or find more. There’s enough material here for a lifetime of social work. Looking ahead, they see the front verandah of the D U whe drunken frat member walks toward its balustrade and dramatically falls, front-flipping, over it and disappear from view. He then stands and walks calmly back into the club. ON the girls: Lily’s shocked expression, the others’ equanimity: VIOLET (CONT’D) What’s really worrisome is that that-- (she makes a face) -- was intentional. The girls pass through the frame toward the clubhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entering it’s instantly clear the girls greatly outclass D.U. guys, a “meatloaf crowd” that includes Violet’s FRAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, this is Lily, she’s just come to Seven Oaks as a transfer student. Isn’t she great?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Lily failed or was unhappy at her last school but we're sure is going to adapt beautifully here. In fact she already has!!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh. Good. A good, quite recent (circa-2002/6) dance hit starts to p

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Omigod -- a “golden oldie.” I love these! Violet starts the dancing; they all join in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four pair off and dance enthusiastically with klutzy partners -- Violet with Frank, etc. Later women arrivals on jealously. Violet tries out new, cool dance steps -- t others follow suit. The dancing gets better. Even the DU guys -- most sad-sacks but one, THOR, dumb and handsome - rise to the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaking from the dancing Violet leads them into the refreshment area.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Omigosh! Wasn’t that great?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: That was really fun.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I know that people can have useful careers in many areas: Government. Law. Finance. --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: --Education--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, even education! But I’d like to do something especially significant in my lifetime, the sort of thing that could change the course of human history -- such as starting a new dance craze.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. Something that could improve the lives of every person -- and every couple. Frank looks at Violet with pride, which Violet rewards wi quick kiss before sampling the punch. VIOLET (CONT’D) My gosh that’s good! What’s in it? The young bartender gets flustered with an “uh...” “duh.. reaction -- he doesn’t know. VIOLET (CONT’D) No, don’t tell. It’s better a mystery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At breakfast the four are in pretty good shape considerin the night before.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m so proud of what you accomplished last night. You showed those guys a really good time without anything really bad happening. You could see their confidence and enjoyment increase by the minute, while not letting them turn into animals. That's good.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Still, I hate it when they puke. Violet thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That’s okay. It’s part of growing up -- “they're learning their limits.”  10.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: But are they learning? It’s like a puking festival.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, their aim’s improving! They're getting more directional!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yuck. I hate when it gets on your clothes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Dar-fur.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Dar-fur. There are horrible injustices in the world and we shouldn’t obsess over the adolescent misdemeanors of friends.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: The guys you know, are they all Greeks?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Are all the guys you know Greeks?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Excuse me? I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (more slowly) Are. All. The. Guys. You. Know. Greeks? Violet looks to the others.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I don’t think we know any Greeks.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Professor Papadapoulos?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: “Greeks” -- frat boys. Blank looks all around.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh Yes! Fraternities! You mean members of Greek-letter  10 11. fraternities -- American college slang: “Greeks.”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Like last night. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Actually last night we were at the “D” “U" house: “D", “U,” Roman letters, not Greek. Seven Oaks doesn’t have a Greek letter fraternity system -- it’s always been a Roman letter system here.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: It's very different.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, I think you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach another Georgian brick building. Rose and Heather carry a large box of donuts and “jug 0’ joe.”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What house is this?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, this isn’t a fraternity -- at least not one anyone should want to join! The sign reads: “Suicide Center.” Violet picks up the “Prevention” from the Center’s sign f the floor. VIOLET (CONT’D) (to Lily) You probably think we’re frivolous, empty-headed, perfume-obsessed college coeds. You’re probably right. I often feel empty headed-- Violet puts the “Prevention” sign back up. VIOLET (CONT’D) But we’re also trying to make a difference in people’s lives. And one way to do that is to stop them from killing themselves.  11 12. Violet and Lily climb the Center steps. VIOLET (CONT’D) Have you ever heard the expression, “Prevention is nine-tenths the cure?” Well, in the case of suicide, it’s actually ten-tenths the cure.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Those are cliches, aren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Heather and Rose set up the coffee and donuts for t center, including the sign explaining their restricted us

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: {Yes, they are.] It’s interesting that you say that. I love cliches and hackneyed expressions of every kind. Do you know why? Lily shakes her head “no.” VIOLET (CONT’D) Because they’re largely true: The hundreds, perhaps thousands of such cliches and hackneyed expressions our language has bequeathed to us are, in fact, a treasure-trove of human insight and understanding.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. Oh, come sit with us. During these formative college years we should try to learn as many hackneyed thoughts and expressions as possible -- furthermore, I think we will!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: (to Lily) Speaking of suicide prevention, do you have a boyfriend, Lily? Lily is a bit amazed.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Are you dating anyone?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I don’t see the connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don’t?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Boyfriends are a primary suicide risk.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: You don’t have any particular friend? No one at all? Lily is put on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No... Well, there’s this grad student whom I met over the summer - - Xavier [pronounce Zav-ee-yay]. We became pretty good pals.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: “Good pals?” What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well, he has a girlfriend whom I met -- she’s very nice. Violet looks around to the others.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What’s the point of that?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Of what?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Xavier with the girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: “Zavier" with a “Z?"

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, I think it’s with an “xX.”

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: No, I’m certain it’s a “Z." “Zavier" Like “Zorro.” It’s the same sound. (does a Zorro move) Zorro marked his name with a “Z."

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It’s an “xX.”  14.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But Zorro’s with a “Z." It’s the same.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s see if we can figure this out. Used at the beginning of a name, “Z" and “X"” have the same pronunciation.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But it’s Zorro- with a “Z.”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Actually there were two “Zorros.” One spelt his name with a “Z" and made a “Z" mark for Zorro, the other one spelled him name with an “X" and with his sword he’d make an “X" mark. What was really unfair was that, because he marked his name with an “X”, everybody assumed he was illiterate, when actually he was spelling correctly. A frantic seeming young male student bursts into the Cent they all stop what they’re doing.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Can we help you?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Of course we can! No case is too hard or challenging -- would you like a donut? Heather springs into action.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Please sit down.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Here, have some coffee. Violet sits at the desk and takes out a form.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What’s your name?  15.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Jim. Bose. But my friends call me Jimbo.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why do your friends call you “Jimbo?”

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: I suppose it’s a contraction of “Jim” and the first part of my last name, “Bose.”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yah. I got that. But, why bother.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why bother: “Jim” is already a lovely name -- short, simple, evocative -- shouldn’t a nickname simplify the name that it’s replacing? Jimbo’ doesn’t simplify anything.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, maybe you should ask your friends what they had in mind. (reading from form) Where do you live or reside?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Doar Dorm.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Ouf.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Omigod. Yuck.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The smell. It’s notorious.  16.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What smell?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You're right, it’s more like a “stink.” Unclean clothing, I'd say, mostly.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Stale beer.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Pot, cheap deodorant -- there might be a vermin infestation. Heather and Lily place the coffee and donut next to him.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No wonder you’re depressed, living there. Did you know that a good smelling environment is crucial to our well-being? Have you thought of moving and finding a place that smells better?--

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: (getting frantic) Wait, wait, wait-- It’s not me -- I’m not depressed!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Because you kind of seem on edge.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: No -- I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That's a terrible expression -- “fine.” (a funny voice) “I'm fine.” (normal voice) Anyone who says they’re fine definitely isn’t. It’s kind of conceited. Something smug about it.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why do you say you're “fine?”

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: I mean I’m not depressed! I’m not suicidal!  12 17. Violet snatches the donut from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Why are you here then? Are you a con man, a confidence trickster?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: No, there’s a girl on my floor! Her boyfriend dumped her! She’s been crying for days but now’s silent--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Omigod! Why didn’t you say so! Violet jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We have to go! (to the others) Call the cops -- a suicide might be in progress! Violet heads off.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: The campus cops?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes of course the campus cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head quickly along the walk. Violet still holds the partially eaten donut carefully and sanitarily with a thi tissue.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Take this. I’m sorry-- Violet gives Jimbo his donut back.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s just that we get a lot of students coming to the center pretending to be depressed to get the donuts.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Confidence tricksters!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s really bad, really cynical. And we made a pledge the donut company that we would only give the donuts to students who were depressed, suicidal or  13 18. otherwise nutty. We’re a non-profit -- so the rules are pretty strict. Jimbo nods as he jogs, his mouth full.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: This man could still be a trickster.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We'll soon find out... I’m surprised we haven’t had more cases from Doar Dorm -- living in such squalor must be terribly destabilizing psychologically.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: It’s not so bad.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You poor guy!... Tell me about this girl.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Her name's “Priss.” She’s very pretty--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah-- (to the other girls) --it’s very hard for beautiful women to experience rejection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are outside the girl’s room. Violet tests the door handle. It’s locked. She shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Priss? Priss? Are you okay? They listen but can hear nothing.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Priss! Say something! Meanwhile each reacts to the Doar Dorm odor: most gasping Rose spraying perfume on her pashmina and trying to breat through that.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Priss! Open up -- please! Priss! She listens but there’s no sound from within. Rose approaches Violet, looking unwell.  19.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (in terrible shape) Could I wait outside?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes! It’s best to get as far away as possible! Rose, who looks shaken, nods.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, take care of yourself. Rose leaves, protecting her face with the pashmina.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Priss say something! Please!-- Campus cops arrive. VIOLET (CONT’D) Oh thank God, we're going to have to force this door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The campus cops burst into the room -- followed by Violet the others. PRISS bolts up from her dorm cot, where she’d been lying teary-eyed, head under a pillow, headphones in ears. She’s delicate-looking and very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Priss?! Are you okay?! Priss takes the headphones out of her ears.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Please don’t-- Please, please-- Come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet & Jimbo sit with Priss who nurses a hot chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: But you had contemplated suicide?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: What?  20.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Had you resolved to kill yourself?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: No... Not really. She stops, looks down and freezes. Silently, tears start streaming down her face. Violet turns to Jimbo:

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Could you excuse us? Jimbo nods and goes. Violet turns back to Priss. VIOLET (CONT’D) Do you want to talk about it? What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: J-josh. Priss’s voice breaks; another wave of tears rolls down he cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: If you'd rather not talk about it, we don’t have to -- Priss nods, but the tears don’t stop.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: No it’s Okay, I just... I keep thinking how... he used to gaze at me with such love in his eyes -- you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I’ve never actually seen that.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Yes, just days ago he’d gaze at me - - with his eyes so blue. She stops; the tears roll some more.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: He had blue eyes? Priss nods.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So does Frank -- Frank’s the guy that I go out with. Otherwise he’s not conventionally good-looking -- which I actually prefer. Would you describe “Josh” as handsome?  21. Priss nods, too overwhelmed to talk further.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s a problem. Lily comes by with a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Could I join you guys?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes, please. Priss and I were just talking -- in my view, handsome men are to be avoided. I don’t even consider good looks to be flattering in a man. Do you know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Uh, no.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Cookie-cutter “good-looking guys” with their “chiseled features,” running around, full of themselves, getting everything they want, never suffering or experiencing any--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Have we suffered?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We're not under discussion-- That's irrelevant, beside the point. (to Priss) Is this making you feel any better? Priss has stopped crying.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Yes. I think so.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Good! I hoped it would. (checks her phone) Okay, it’s nearly four and the Daily Complainer’s orientation meeting is about to start. I think we should go. The editor, Rick DeWolfe, he’s terrible, a real jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fab Four plus Priss walk toward the “Daily Complainer building.  22.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why do you think he’s such a jerk?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Environment? Genetics?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I mean what’s he done that’s so jerky?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh. You’ll see. He’s one of those I was talking about -- tall, probably considering himself very smart and handsome -- and a “journalist” -- so you can just imagine the mind-boggling arrogance and conceit.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But, Violet, don’t you think...

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well, don’t you think that the way you talk be considered arrogant too? They walk in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, a little...

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, but what’s your point?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well...wouldn’t that be hypocritical, criticizing Rick DeWolfe for something you could be criticized for yourself? Violet considers this with complete equanimity.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I don’t see why... We’re all flawed. Must that render us mute to the flaws of others? Must we tether ourselves from comment because our natures are human too? (very happy) We've got a rebel amongst us! That's good, I think. It’s good to be challenged and criticized.  23.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I know your intentions are good--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You’ve put your finger on something important. That’s it, precisely: Our intentions are good. We’re seeking to help people rescue their lives from terrible sadness and failure -- which is a worthy goal, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes, but not exactly a humble one.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I agree with you there, you're right absolutely. I’d like to thank you for this chastisement.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I think you did and I think it’s good. It’s good to have a friend to put one in one’s place when that’s what one needs and now I see that I have that kind of friend in you. I think that’s great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall, insufferable RICK DeWOLFE jumps up on a steel desk address the young freshman and sophomore crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RICK DE WOLFE
dialogues.text: Hello, people. Listen up... People! Quiet... Quiet, people... Shut up!... Okay, that's better! Ha, ha. I'm Rick DeWolfe, editor of the Complainer. Over the next weeks and months I’m the person you’1l learn to hate most in the world. At least, I hope so! (laughs) You’re going hate me because I’m going to work you relentlessly, point out your stupidity and incompetence, do everything in my power to turn you into journalists - - albeit barely literate ones. Nervous laughter from the crowd.  24.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh brother!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What? Violet just shakes her head but Rick looks and sees Viole contemptuous stare. A Ceausescu moment. Then he recovers.

dialogues.speaker: RICK DE WOLFE
dialogues.text: Any questions?... No? Stupid titters. Violet rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Uh, yes -- how did the “Daily Complainer” get its name?

dialogues.speaker: RICK DE WOLFE
dialogues.text: Isn't that pretty obvious? The student, embarrassed, shakes his head; nervous titter from the crowd. RICK DE WOLFE (CONT’D) It comes out every day and it’s the university daily-- So, the Daily. Complainer. Daily-- Stupid laughter, from Rick and others.

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: No, I meant--

dialogues.speaker: RICK DE WOLFE
dialogues.text: You mean why the “Complainer?” The name dates from Seven Oak’s earliest days as a divinity school. The reference is to the Book of Job -- Job’s “complaint” with the world. The Complainer started as a theological journal but evolved into the university weekly, finally going daily after World War Two. I like the name -- before justice can be achieved, a complaint must be made. That’s what we do and people don't like it a bit. Right now that means extirpating Seven Oak’s elitist roman-letter clubs that are like a cancer on the university community-—

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh what nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: RICK DE WOLFE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not “elitist” in the least. Dead silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Of course they are.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Have you met any of their members? The guys from the DU, for example? They're morons, barely competent for the tasks of everyday life. They have to drink something like a quart of beer just to talk toa woman-—

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Two quarts.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yet you salivate at the idea of taking the roof off these poor guys’ heads, and throwing them brutally into the street where who knows what harm might come to them. And you consider yourself a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: No, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What unkindness and cruelty -- and yet you’re proud of that. This is the darkness in human nature, in the very Heart of Man -- which the British novelist Joseph Conrad wrote about most eloquently.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: He was actually Polish.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Omigod! Pedantic too! Unkind, self-righteous and pedantic -- in short, a model journalist! Rick looks around and appeals to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: You should know something about these girls -- they run the “Suicide Center” where their preferred therapy for seriously depressed and suicidal people is +..tap dancing. I kid you not. 25.  26.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Tap is a highly effective therapy as well as a dazzlingly expressive dance form that has been sadly neglected for too many years.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: It’s moronic and barbaric. You seriously expect tap dancing to solve these people’s problems?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, we don’t -- we're using the whole range of musical dance numbers which over many years have proven themselves to be effective therapies for the suicidal and hopelessly depressed. 18 INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- NIGHT 18 Violet lies on her bunk, looking discouraged, while the others relax or go about their business.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That really got me down.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I thought you handled it well.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You did? Thanks. No, it’s all this aggression and hostility that gets me down -- not just his, but also my own. It leaves you feeling unclean.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Have you thought of taking a shower maybe you’d fee better.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You’re probably right but there's something else... What Lily was saying about me being conceited and arrogant-——

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I think you’re right. It’s bad. I feel terrible.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You’re joking--  19 27.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I’m serious. It’s terrible how I’ve acted. I’m embarrassed.... We’re all Christians -- Or, I should say “Judeo-Christians:” humility should be our watchword, the essence of being a good person. The question is, how do you become humble if you’re essentially arrogant and... evil by nature? The room falls into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gangly, oddly-dressed male student awkwardly leads sad- seeming students, including Priss, in a tap dance number if from a 30s musical. [Look for music. ]

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Very good, Freak!

dialogues.speaker: GANGLY STUDENT
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes! Certainly. Lily takes Violet aside.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Is it really such a good idea to call him “freak”?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: He’s already depressed; constantly calling him “freak”--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (whispers back) That’s his name, “Freak” -- “Freak Astaire,” that’s how he wants to be called. “FREAK ASTAIRE” -- the gangly student -- notices them talking.

dialogues.speaker: FREAK
dialogues.text: (a bit paranoid) What’s all the whispering? What are you talking about?  28.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Lily was just saying that she likes your dancing. Freak nods. Next to them DEBBIE, a chorus member, seems catatonic. VIOLET (CONT’D) Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (suspiciously) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I just noticed that you looked a little sad and I was wondering if there’s anything we could do.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What could you do? Oh, I know: you think I’m suicidal -- that I’m going to kill myself and make you look bad.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I’m worried you’1l kill yourself and make yourself look bad.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Do you have you any idea how demoralizing it is to be constantly questioned about whether you're suicidal or not?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Well, the first few times, you might brush it aside by saying “No” or “Not now...” (Increasingly angry) ...-But, after a while, you begin to wonder -- why is everyone asking me this? Is it because they want me to be suicidal? Or is it just the unintended consequence of their utter absurdity? Debbie turns and walks away; Violet follows her.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Excuse me, what scent are you wearing?  20 29.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The perfume that you’re wearing.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I’m not wearing any perfume!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You see, that could be the problem. INT XAVIER’S HOUSE, KITCHEN -- EVENING 20 The kitchen in the ground floor apartment in a private ho Lily’s grad student friend XAVIER and his girlfriend ALIC the midst of preparing a healthy-looking meal.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’ve become friends with this really nice group...

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Reall? Yeah -- though they’re somewhat perfume-obsessed.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Oh them -- those girls? The ones who volunteer at the Suicide Center?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: But they’re terrible! The blonde one -- she’s notorious.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Such a bitch, terrible, isn’t she?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: (preparing the salad) Would balsamic be okay?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Balsamic vinegar, for the dressing?  21 30.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, sure. Lily follows their movements as they prepare the meal. Xavier lifts a lid revealing three artichokes in a cloud steam.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?!

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Those.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Artichokes?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Is that what they look like?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Lily. You’ve seen an artichoke before... Lily is embarrassed for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven't?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: They look so weird! Like little Martian space vehicles. Xavier laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls leaving the Suicide Center with Priss.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You know, I’m not convinced that having a “Suicide Prevention Center” prevents any suicides.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, the coffee’s good.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: If someone were really determined to destroy themselves, I don’t think they’d stop for coffee.  31.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I suppose it depends on what it tastes like.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I thought I’d take Priss over to the D.U.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, it might be helpful for her to meet some of the guys.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How would that be helpful? They’re morons.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Come on, Lily.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, they are. They’re morons.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No. Not medically... I like them. They're in that sympathetic range of being not good-looking, and yet not smart. There’s something likeable about that. Spending time with them, you get the sense that you’re really making a difference in their lives. For somebody suicidal, like Priss, that could be a real boost.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: I’m not suicidal.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh. That's good. It's better not to have the identity as a suicidal person, don’t you think? Lily heads down a divergent path.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (worried) Where’re you going?  22 32.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Over to Xavier's.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Is that a good idea?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t it be?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Is his girlfriend going to be there?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Of course -- gosh you’re nosy.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No -- no nose. Just a general foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: “Foreboding?” Violet reconsiders.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You know, you’re absolutely right! I was being nosy, terribly so. I’ve got to watch that. Please forgive me. I want to become a better person. Can one? Can one change one’s nature? I don’t know. But I feel we must try.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, we must improve ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: DAMSELS
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the golden light of the day’s end Lily approaches Xavi house. A guy on a bike passes her.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Lily! Xavier stops.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were coming over?  23 Lily, surprised, nods. Xavier gets off his bike.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yeah, is Alice home?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Alice is working.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Oh, she is?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: But it’s not a problem -- it’s good you came. Let’s go to the Oak Bar; I‘1l buy you a beer. Lily hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I thought Alice would be back.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I’‘1l call her. She’ll join us there. Lily hesitates further.
23 Xavier and Lily, installed at a booth, talk as the tavern starts to fill up with local and student crowds.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: She’s actually quite a good person. I mean, her entire identity revolves around helping people.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You really think that’s true? For instance, what's she have against the Complainer? That’s bizarre.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well, she thinks the editor, Rick DeWolfe, is completely egotistical.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: And your friend isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hi! Xavier stands to let Alice by him into the booth.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Hey!  34.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Hi Lily!

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Hi! Great! You got the message.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks. So, who’s egotistical?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Lily’s roommate. She sounds unbearable. She’s on a rampage against the Complainer.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: She thinks the editor, Rick DeWolfe, is conceited and, in fact, quite mean.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Mean?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes, he wants to close Seven Oaks’ Roman-letter clubs.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: That's good isn’t it? I thought everyone was against them.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Come on. There’s no possible justification for those places. They're exclusive and elitist.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: The point that Violet makes is that they can’t be elitist, they’re morons.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Yeah -- elitist morons. Confounded for a second, Lily regroups.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But you’ll grant that they’re morons and that’s a handicap -- such people should be helped, not hounded and persecuted.  24 35.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) Persecuted?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes. Losing the roof over your head, being thrown out into the street, that’s about the worst thing that can happen to anyone. Xavier shrugs, cruelly indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Violet thinks that there could be some risk of... suicide.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Oh, because some moronic frat boy might kill himself, Seven Oaks can’t do what’s right?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It’s a factor to be taken into consideration.

dialogues.speaker: ALICE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: No it isn’t. You can’t set policy that way. The barman arrives with a new round of drinks.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, we didn’t order these--

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Compliments of the guy at the bar. They look to the bar, where a well-dressed fairly young g nods to them. Lily looks at him intently -- while he’s no handsome, there’s something appealing about him. INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 24 Lily paces as the girls lounge in the room.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That’s a playboy or oper-a-tor move. Oper-a-tors like that are to be avoided.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why? It seems very generous to me - - sending a round of drinks over to  36. people he didn’t know? Drinks are expensive.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Sending drinks to two gorgeous girls? His intention was to seduce -- and he assumed he could.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: (shocked) Both?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Isn't that a bit harsh? He was probably just yearning for some intelligent discourse.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I doubt that was the course he was seeking.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Was he alone?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You see -- he was alone and probably lonely. He could see that Alice and Lily are college students. College students are well known for their intelligent conversation. After all they can always talk about their courses. That was probably what attracted him--

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Perhaps his view was even loftier -- to court Lily, with a view to Matrimony. We’re in the North but occasionally a Southern gentleman can wander into these parts.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why not? Seeing Lily across a crowded bar, filled with the usual undergraduate slobs, why wouldn’t a thoughtful young man seek her out? She’s lovely. Isn’t it incumbent on men and women to find ways to meet each other? Buying drinks for  37. a person you don’t know seems to me to be a particularly generous one.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yes, most guys won’t even pay for the women they do know.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What you’ve described is a playboy or oper-a-tor move.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’‘ll grant you it’s a tactic, or perhaps even a ruse. But without some of that, would our species even survive? The Lord said, “Be fruitful and multiply--”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigosh--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, this is how the world works -- “seeing someone across a room” -- this could be a great romantic story to tell your grandchildren. Violet imagines this.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if you do marry and have children then he'll learn how to really squander cash. Isn’t it good to know he’s basically generous from the start.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Where’s Priss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priss sits with Frank as a D.U brother, THOR, makes drink

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Your eyes are so striking, so blue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Really? They're blue?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Yes. The most piercing blue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Huhn.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: You must know that your eyes are blue?  38.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: (laughs) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: You must know what color your eyes are. Frank remains silent and impassive.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, your eyes are very blue, you know that.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m not going to go around “checking” what color my eyes are!... At the bar Thor cocks his head, listening.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Yes, but-- When you look in a mirror, you must see your eyes are blue.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh come on!

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I’m not homo-phobic, but I’m not going to go looking in mirrors, checking to see what color my eyes are!... I don’t think my eyes have a color. If they were so blue, looking out, wouldn't everything be kind of blue? Like, have a blue tinge or something? (looks around) Doesn't. Just looks normal. Thor, handing them drinks, takes a look at Frank’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: That’s blue? That color?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Yes. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, what color is that? He points to a leather chair that’s clearly green.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Green.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: You’re saying that chair’s green, but Frank’s eyes are blue?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: And was color are the walls?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Also, green.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Huhn.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: You don’t know that?

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: How is that possible?

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: You really think knowing the colors is so, so important?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: You’re in college and you don’t know colors?... Doesn’t that embarrass you?

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: No. Why should it? That’s why the ‘rents are paying big bucks to send me here -- you know, to learn stuff. Thor toasts them, taking a sip from his drink.

dialogues.speaker: THOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks. Well, gotta go hit the books. Thor heads off, then stops.  26 27 40.

dialogues.speaker: THOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know about you but I don’t think anyone should feel embarrassed about not knowing stuff. What’s embarrassing is pretending to know what you don’t -- or putting other people down just because you think they don’t know as much as you. I’m happy to admit I’m completely ignorant. That’s why I’m here and plan to really hit the books. So, the next time you see me, I’1l1 know more than I do now. I’1l be older, but also wiser -- or at least know more stuff. For me, that’s education. Thor salutes them with his drink. THOR (CONT’D) Cheers. Thor takes a long draught before leaving. Priss and Frank watch Thor go.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thor’s great. He’s very clear about his objectives: he really wants to learn things -- that’s why he’s here. Like, you always see him with a book and yet he’s not pretentious in the least...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are low. Some cool music is on. The camera swoops up the stairs, passes through a doorway and enters club “nest” area -- finding Priss and Frank in passionate embrace. Their kiss goes on and on. Reverse angle: Violet, Rose, Heather and Lily at the doorway, shocked. Violet turns and flees, the others foll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls walk silently and somberly, Violet’s face turne down, in a state of shock.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What a jerk.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: He’s a monster.  4l.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Omigosh, Violet. You did everything for them! They’re nothing without you! Tears have started rolling down Violet’s face.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What a rat.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Moron.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Don’t waste a single tear on that creep.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Don't waste a single breath.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Jerk.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Stop- Please...

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (a quiet voice) I. Love. Frank. (a strange, intense voice) I love him. 28 INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 28 The next day they’re still talking -- Violet prostrate ab

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Come on, Violet, Frank’s a moron. You're well rid of him.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Don’t say that.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What, Frank’s not a moron?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You know, Lily, you’re a bit harsh. This obsession with “intelligence” — - do you think it has some magical quality, transforming everything? The intelligence line is not an... immutable barrier; love can cross it. You can love someone whose  42. mental capacity is not large... I know; I have.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well, there’s a mutable barrier then.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Frank's stupid, we knew. That he was a rat jerk playboy op-er-a-tor I hadn’t realized.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I don’t want to turn bitter. I worry for Frank -- I care about him.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well, I’d stop.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No. I love Frank -- I always will.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: If that’s the case, why not fight for him?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Get him back.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No! He’s worthless!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Against Priss? I’d never win.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Sure you would.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Priss, who’s so pretty and sweet?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Priss is a rat. A bitch. A rat- bitch.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Don’t blame Priss. She was crushed when her blue-eyed Josh left her. (smiles a little crazily) I should have known. Of course she'd fall for Frank. Josh and Frank are both blue-eyed heartbreakers. Lily looks at Violet as if she were completely delusional  43.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I wonder if people with blue eyes are in fact less kind than other people. Blue eyes could represent an icy nature.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Your eyes are blue.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I know, and I’m often shocked at how cold I am. I’m like an icicle inside. I don’t feel a thing.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: The Algebra of Love

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily walks with the guy who sent the drinks over to them the bar, CHARLIE WALKER.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Poor Violet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: She’s the roommate who’s so self- confident and constructive?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yeah -- but now she’s a wreck... But there’s no logic to the algebra of love.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “The Algebra of Love?” (smiles) That sounds like the title to some lame book.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a title, but the book’s not lame at all.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Love’s “algebra?” I always thought it was more geometry.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Okay, the title’s not good, but the book is.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’s it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that while we’re all... perverse in our romantic preferences, there’s actually this logic, or algebra, to our perversity. It has something to do with how the species has evolved.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The survival of the species?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes, and whether it will continue to do so...
30 Lily drains a martini glass and puts it down next to an e one.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Just to find the nearest package store you had to drive forty miles. (sips) These aren’t so strong--

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, they’re really strong. Lily looks a little woozy.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I think I'd like another.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: That wouldn’t be a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Are you trying to stifle me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lily?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Listen, we’re going to get something to eat, why don’t you come with us?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m with Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I can see that. But you really should come.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I just think it would be a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You really must come. I insist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily walks slightly ahead and separate from Xavier and Al silent and angry. She might be a little tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Lily? She just keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lily, are you angry? Lily passes the front of a restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lily! This is it. We’re here. She returns, as if reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: That was so rude. He’s a nice guy and you embarrassed him.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: He’s not nice at all. He was trying to get you drunk.  32 46.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, he wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Plying you with martinis? What a sleaze-ball.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I was plying myself with martinis--

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Come on, the guy’s a total sleaze, a creep.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You don’t know anything about him--

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: The way he sent drinks over to our table? Alice, fed up, turns and walks quickly away. Xavier chase her.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alice! Alice! What’s wrong?! INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 32 Tight on Violet’s face, as she lies on her bed, her face lightly angled toward the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I just had no idea Xavier could be so mean. While the chat centers on Lily, the camera also observes Violet’s post-jilt pain.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Are you sure he was mean?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Sounds as if he was just trying to protect you.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: This Charlie Walker sounds like an oper-a-tor, a “playboy” type.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: He’s not like that at all, he’s actually a really nice guy.  33 34 47.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I thought he was a slick businessman.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, he dresses well but he works in strategic development.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: “Strategic Development” -- he works at “S.D.A.” -- Strategic Development Associates. He’s an associate there.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What he is is a “strategic oper-a- tor.” Lily notices Violet, turned to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Violet? Are you okay? For a while Violet says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet strides between sports fields, heading toward the countryside as the sky darkens ominously. A maintenance m riding a small grass-cutter calls to her:

dialogues.speaker: GROUNDS KEEPER
dialogues.text: Hey! Miss! Rain’s comin’ -- better go back. Violet nods but keeps on walking. Thunder sounds. Violet continues; the sound of rain.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT 34
dialogues.text: Lily and Rose pass their neighbor POSITIVE POLLY in the stairwell.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Polly! Have you seen Violet?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: No, is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.  35 36 37 48. Outside, Lily and Rose look for Violet, calling, and ente wood.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: (alternating) Violet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet walks back from the wood; Lily and Rose find her.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Violet omigosh-- what happened?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls wait as steam pours out of a shower stall.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand, what were you doing? There is no response -- just the sound of water.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How long were you gone for? Violet is still slow to reply.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I don’t know -- I lost track of time. The girls exchange concerned looks. Violet gets out of th shower, wrapped in a towel.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But you feel better now? Violet, listless in her movements, is slow to reply.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well... cleaner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Debbie and Freak practice dance; Jimbo quizzes Violet for questionnaire.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: She’1l say anything to get in the show. I suppose now she’1ll want the donuts, too--  38 49.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: You don’t have to be suicidal to get the donuts, just “severely depressed.”

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: No, “clinically depressed” -- from a clinic.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: (to Violet) Would you say that you’re depressed?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I don’t like the term “depressed” -- I prefer to say that I’m ina tailspin.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Omigod! A “tail spin!” She can’t even say she’s “depressed” like everyone else -- she’s got to say something “special.” Priss was honest, she was really depressed and she had a right to be in the show. Now every silly tail-spinner is trying to get in!

dialogues.speaker: FREAK
dialogues.text: The show’s for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: No, it isn’t, Freak! To be included in the Center’s programs you have to be “clinically depressed.” That means that you’ve been to a clinic -- and they've said that you’re depressed. Have you been to a clinic? Violet doesn’t reply.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you been to a clinic? Violet shakes her head “no.”

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then you're not “clinically depressed.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heather arrives with a large tray of donuts and cardboard coffee jug as Violet leaves the building.  39 40 41 42 50.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Violet, Violet? What is it, where are you going? Violet stops but doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (in a leaden monotone) All I wanted was to make Frank happy... I’d all these plans, things we could’ve done together. I never even got to tell him... Violet goes off, leaving Heather watching after her. INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 39 Violet looks in the mirror then goes to her desk to write note. She looks around for a good spot to place it, final leaving it at the foot of her bed. But as she opens the door, a breeze ruffles the window curtain and lifts the n which flutters under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet, walks across the low bridge, stops halfway across gazes into the water below. The water swirls and eddies.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Polly, have you seen Violet?

dialogues.speaker: POLLY
dialogues.text: No, she left the dorm at four and I haven’t seen her since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boorish shouts of moronic male students on a walkway the otherwise deserted Quadrangle a forlorn air. INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- NIGHT 42 Lily looks down onto the scene, then turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine where she could have gone? Wherever she went, she should be back by now. Rose turns to Heather.  51.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: How did she seem when you last saw her?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Really sad about Frank.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: still? Heather nods.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m beginning to wonder about Violet. How can someone so smart continue mooning over a dope like that.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: From what I’ve observed in my admittedly brief span on earth, people generally don’t jump for joy after being dumped by the moronic jerk in whom they’ve invested all their hopes and dreams.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But Violet’s so great, how could she go berserk over an idiot like that?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: People aren’t exactly as you assume. The Violet you know bears little resemblance to the girl I met Seventh Grade year--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You met Violet in Seventh Grade?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, her name wasn’t “Violet” then. A “wavy” memory dissolve begins as Rose thinks back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shyly entering, timid 11 year old EMILY TWEETER resembles character we know as “Violet” physically but in no other

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ROSE
dialogues.text: What’s your name?  52. Emily doesn’t immediately respond.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You can tell us your name. We won't bite. GIRL #1 laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: What’s your name? Tell us.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Are you retarded? Tell us your name? Speak!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Emily... Tweeter.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: “Tweeter?” Like a bird?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous! 44 INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- NIGHT 44 Present day.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: “Tweeter?” Like a bird?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes -- not an easy name to have at that age.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Not at any age. What was she like?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Timid, bookish... classic scholarship student -- her parents were writers. They didn’t have a dime. Finances were the least of her worries.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, she was crazy -- I got stuck rooming with her on the class trip when no one else would. Ouf, it was awful.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: She smelled bad?  53.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No. Obsessive cleanliness was part of her insanity.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But you were nice to her.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No, not really -- the idea of being nice to weird and unpopular kids hadn't arrived then.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why was she so unpopular?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She was very strange -- constantly setting herself odd, repetitive tasks--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Tasks?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: For example on that trip she had with her a little square suitcase. The idea came into her head she had to move it in a precise pattern, over and over again... Images of young “Emily” attempting this as a young “Rose” watches, expression agape.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If she didn’t execute this exact movement, flawlessly, ten times -- she'd start over from scratch. Looks from the others.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Another was to slide her hand across her forehead, trying not to touch her hair or her eyebrows on either side -- (Rose demonstrates) -- also repeating it ten times. Any niggling thought she touched a hair on either side, she’d start over.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: My God that’s insane!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Why would she do that?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Well, it was a compulsion.  44n 45 46 47 54.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What compelled her?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: She had the superstitious conviction that if she didn’t complete these tasks flawlessly -- her parents would die.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Was she Catholic?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No. But what made the whole thing really sad was that her parents did die.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heather riding with the campus cops, looking all over; th lacrosse and girls hockey teams searching along the marsh near the playing fields, using their sticks to push aside reeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet showering [PG-acceptable], letting the water wash her head. She notices the scent of the soap and, shutting off the water, inhales of it deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet in a towel, her hair moist but combed, goes about room getting dressed. Before leaving she retrieves the so inhales its scent again, and carefully packs it in plasti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the counter CAROLINA ANTONUCCI, a sympathetic but rath thin-skinned waitress, fills Violet’s coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: Something's wrong, isn’t it, dear? Violet, surprised, looks up. CAROLINA (CONT’D) Do you mind my asking?  55.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well... I do mind, a little.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: Oh well! Excuse me, your Highness! Carolina stalks to the other end of the counter, refillin the coffees of two highway groundsmen there on their brea

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- it’s just that it’s kind of awkward to talk about.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: No matter... I just hope you haven’t come down here to get run over on the highway. Carolina rolls her eyes at the highway groundsmen.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY WORKER 1
dialogues.text: Suicides. They come down from the university. Jump out in the road to get hit by the blind curve--

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY WORKER 2
dialogues.text: Hope you’re not one of them.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Do I look like one of them?

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY WORKER 2
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY WORKER 1
dialogues.text: Messy people, suicides. Think only of themselves and their own deaths - - not what comes after.

dialogues.speaker: HIGHWAY WORKER 2
dialogues.text: They make quite a mess, but don’t stick around to clean it up.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: So you’re not one of those depressed students down from the university?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t really like the word “depressed;” I prefer to say that I’m in a tailspin.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLINA
dialogues.text: A Tail Spin?  48 49 56. SHARISE, a young black waitress, coming on duty, takes an interest.

dialogues.speaker: SHARISE
dialogues.text: Does this Tail Spin involve a Man?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. It does. But I’m not as crazy as I was up to yesterday. Partly that’s due to the salutary effect of scent on the human psyche. It’s importance is, I believe, almost incalculable. At the motel this morning I happened to use this bar of soap-- Violet shows the soap in a see-through plastic zip-lock b VIOLET (CONT’D) It was provided me as a courtesy as one of its guests -- that an economical motel would provide such good soap is quite unusual. The scent is very precise.

dialogues.speaker: SHARISE
dialogues.text: Really? Sharise leans forward. Violet cradles the soap in the pal of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Tell me if it provokes any particular reaction in your psyche - - a state of mind. Sharise and Carolina, then the highway workers, all inhal its scent -- then look thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: the Daily Complainer rolls off the press, the headline “Sophomore Missing!” -- with a picture of Violet

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: I always knew she was unstable. They're going to have her photo at the registrar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet gets off a mid-morning commuter train.  50 51 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet enters at the main gate -- a MALE STUDENT reading Complainer looks up at her, surprised. Shrieks sound from across the quad.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Violet! Violet! Heather runs toward her. HEATHER (CONT’D) You're back! You’re okay!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not really. A campus police Mini pulls up and a cop jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Omigosh, Violet -- we were so worried, why didn’t you tell us or at least leave a note?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I did leave a note.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPUS COP
dialogues.text: Would that be a suicide note? INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 51 Violet looks under the desk and beds, finds the note and hands it to Heather.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t have left without leaving a note.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But where did you go?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I took the commuter train to Villafranca and checked into a cheap motel there.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The Motel 6?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, the Motel 4, it’s even less expensive.  52 53 58.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The Motel 4 in Villafranca - oh my God, you really were suicidal!

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: But why’d you go?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I had to do something.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You really thought you were going to find the answer to whatever you were looking for in Villafranca?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what I expected but I think I might have found it.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What? Violet looks in her bag and pulls out something which she holds cupped in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Soap? Violet bends over her cupped hands and inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: This scent -- and this soap -- is what gives me hope.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I‘1l tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very late afternoon: Lily, with shopping bag, rings, then knocks. No one answers. She knocks again. Then tests the door. It’s open and she hesitantly enters.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Hello?... Hello?... Is anyone here?... Lily walks through the house -- it seems spare, as if furnishings have been removed. A rhythmic sound comes fro somewhere in the apartment. Passing the washer-dryer she  59. it’s the agitated spin cycle. She gets to the kitchen and puts the bag down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigosh, I couldn’t understand where everyone was!

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Sorry, I just went out to get some things. He puts another bag of groceries on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Where’s Alice?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Gone.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Left. We broke up.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But when you called you said--

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I know, I’m sorry. I thought it better to tell you in person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LATER, CUT TO CLOSE ON: Vegetables saute in a pan. Xavier cooks, Lily helps.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Alice couldn't control her jealousy -- it completely overwhelmed her.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Really? What was she jealous of?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Oh come on.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No... what?  55 60.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You. After a while I just couldn't handle it -- things became impossible.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: She was jealous of me?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffee table has been set with two places and low candles. Lily brings in their plates as Xavier looks thro some dvds.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Would it be okay if we watch a film?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes, what would you like to see?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I thought, maybe, Truffaut's “Baisers Voles”, “Stolen Kisses.” Do you know it?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, is it new? Xavier shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
