dialogues.text: It’s a classic of French New Wave cinema -- I think you'll like it. Xavier puts the dvd on and reaches for the wine.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But, it’s in color?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Yeah. Xavier pours them two glasses of wine -- Lily watches. TIGHT ON: red wine pouring into a glass.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t know Truffaut?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Do you know Godard? “A Bout Souffle?” EXT./INT. LIVING ROOM, XAVIER’S HOUSE -- NIGHT 56 Travelling pan of room as closing music of Truffaut film plays. Slouched back on the sofa, Xavier and Lily kiss. INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 57 Heather paces, Lily and Rose study, Violet examining the contents of a small case.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Why was Alice so jealous? Lily just looks thoughtful, continuing studying.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What do you think -- she was jealous because Lily’s absolutely lovely.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I don’t know -- apparently they had a lot of problems.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Of course! You wouldn’t break up a happy couple. Violet is studying a piece of paper she’s taken from the

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: A note Frank left.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Really? Recently?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No -- when we were together. Now that most correspondence is electronic, it’s very rare to be left with anything written by hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Frank can write by hand? What is it?  62.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It's not very important but -- it’s just all I have.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What’s it say? Heather, taking a look, reads it:

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: “Out for brewskis -- back in a... gif.”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What's a “gif”?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: It’s one of those little motor scooters, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sure he meant to write “jiff,” with a “j” -- “back in a jiff.”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But he wrote “gif.”

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Could Frank be dyslexic?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No. Dyslexics are intelligent. Violet handles a little leather-covered ball from the box

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Frank's bean-ball.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: He gave you his bean-ball?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not exactly. This is an extra -- he thought he’d leave it here just in case he lost his other one.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That’s all Frank gave you, a bean- ball?  58 63.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Relationships aren’t about presents.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: They aren't?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Gosh, Violet, you’ve really got to stop thinking about Frank.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why? I don’t want to stop thinking about him. Recently I had a thought that cheered me up a lot: ...-Life is like a long flowing river and, as a long flowing river, some debris you never expect to see again is almost certain to reappear, floating to the surface... Frank and I may very well be together again one day. Maybe it’1ll take many years but somewhere, down the line, he is very likely to pop up again -- and I‘ll be there to catch him. INT. XAVIER’S HOUSE -- NIGHT 58 Great music plays; lots of candles providing flickering illumination. The camera snoops down the hallway to the kitchen, where there are a few dishes left from a dinner deux, to the living room where Lily and Xavier smooch on couch, their clothes undone. Xavier slightly disentangles himself, enough to talk.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: There’s something I wanna... He stops.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m ready. Xavier smiles.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I don’t think we’ve spoken about this--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: It's nothing bad. Have you ever been to the South of France -- for  64. example, to the walled city of Carcassonne.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’ve never been anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: But you’ve seen pictures of it?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Uh... No, I don’t think so. He shows her a postcard of Carcassonne.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's fascinating, I'd like to visit it.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: So you never studied the Cathars? Lily shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They were a religious movement, very idealistic, located mostly in the south of France, that the Catholic Church and the royal authorities cruelly repressed. The “crusades” were not directed solely against the Moslems, there was also one against the Cathars.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Cathar beliefs and way of life threatened the Catholic Church and the political authorities of that time. Catharism was branded a heresy and brutally repressed.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigod, the Catholic Church is, like, always bad. Xavier nods.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Ideas can’t be killed as easily as people -- especially such enlightened ones as the Cathars held. In recent years more and more people have returned to their beliefs.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: So, you’re a Cathar?  59 60 65.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Yes. I aspire to be. I’m trying to follow the path the Cathars marked out.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: That's so impressive. I can tell you -- we didn’t have any Cathars back home.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: I think you’d be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily washing her hands, checking herself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xavier goes between the bedroom and living room lighting candles and rearranging things, placing a lotion near the bed, adjusting the music. Lily, coming out, walks into Xavier’s arms. Xavier leads her to the bed where they continue kissing, finally coming up for air.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Cathars dissent radically from Catholic teaching regarding procreative sex--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I should hope so!

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: In the Cathar view the highest form of love-making avoids procreation entirely. Lily laughs, a little embarrassed:

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Sure -- condoms, right?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Well, according to Cathar ideas, sex with condoms is just a parody of the procreative act. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?  61 62 63 66.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: The standard, cliche, form of sexual intercourse is for the man to... approach the woman... from “the front.” In Cathar love-making -- which, I think you'll find very fulfilling -- it’s from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: From the other side?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Yes. Xavier kisses her tenderly and continues in a near whispe

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘ll be very careful, we’ll go slowly. It’ll be a new experience for you but one which I think you'll find brings an inexpressible closeness... They continue kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time lapse of the turning from night to morning, when Xav lets Lily out, giving a last kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily walks down the street, pensive, looking somewhat uncomfortable, her gait odd.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: Girls’ Night Out The girls having weekend-style cocktails -- drinks that a pink. Violet looks around the bar.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Might your drinks-buying friend be here? It would be great to get some complimentary cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Charlie? No. Lily, looking around, shakes her head.  67.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Do you still see him at all?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yeah, he calls from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: He does? Why don’t you invite him over and introduce us? Lily smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why should I introduce you?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Well, because you know him -- and we don’t.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: “So?” “So” is probably the unkindest word in the English language. I can’t bear it. It should be outlawed: “So.”

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You’re crazy.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Come on, Lily, you have Xavier. You can't keep two guys for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Guys do that all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: We're not “guys,” fortunately...

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: It’s unconscionable for you not to bring him around and introduce us.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Charlie’s a friend. He’s a nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I just hate to think what would happen if one of you got her claws into him.  68.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: That’s outrageous!... We’re perfectly nice people. We’ve met a lot of pathetic guys and nothing very bad’s happened.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Charlie’s not pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well all the better then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily approaches the house. INT. XAVIER’S HOUSE -- EVENING Xavier comes to the door and walks with her inside.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Where were you? Gosh -- it’s late.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I was getting drinks at the Oak Bar.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: With whom?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Just my roommates -- I’ve hardly seen them lately.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You could have called.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: It’s not like you. At all. I got takeout. I suppose I’d better heat it up. He grabs her and they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I was just feeling so... Well, you know. He smiles. He picks up a bag and slips out a small amber cannister.  66 68 69.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got this -- it’s supposed to be great. He hands Lily the elegant bottle.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: A great lotion -- everyone swears by it. Would you prefer dinner first? Lily nods.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I haven't been hurting you, have I? Lily shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily lets herself out and walks down the path and then th sidewalk, her gait careful and pretty awkward.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: The Ides of March -- Beware

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From watching Violet turns back to the others.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: The “Roman Holidays” will be coming soon. Rose groans.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: A festival Seven Oaks’ Roman-letter clubs put on.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: A kind of moron jamboree.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I wish I could say the Roman Holidays were a celebration of the best in classical learning,  70. education, architecture, philosophy -- with poems in the style of Juvenal and recreations of historic events such as Cato’s defense at the bridge. But, alas, it’s --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: A moron jamboree.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The only Roman elements will be worship of Bacchus, Beerus and Blotto and it’s such a shame because it could all have been so uplifting and improving. Charlie Walker, not wearing a suit, enters the cafe. Lily spots him.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Charlie! Charlie! Charlie stops in his tracks and turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! What are you doing here? Charlie pauses for thought.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you the day off?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: This is my friend -- Charlie -- whom I think I’ve mentioned. Charlie, these are my roommates -- this is Rose, this is Heather and Violet. Charlie works at Strategic Development Associates -- he’s an Associate there.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You work in Strategic Development?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You've heard of it?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Of course, yes. My cousin Jay in Philadelphia works in Strategic Development.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: “Stra-tegic Devel-op-ment?” What is that?  71.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, in contradistinction to short- term or “tactical development” -- “strategic development” is planning for the long term.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Something bus-i-ness related?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Mostly business, but any kind of organization.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But only businesses pay the big bucks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Actually, non-profits and government pay well too.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I suppose that’s how they keep from having profits -- by paying lots of money to companies like yours.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Excuse me -- aren’t you in Professor Ryan’s course at the Ed School?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Uh, no.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You’re not in Professor Ryan's “Flit Lit” course?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: “Flit Lit?”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The Dandy Tradition in Literature-- (to Charlie) I’m sure I’ve seen you there.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- I’m not in any courses at the Ed School. (to the group) Well, it was good to meet you.  72. (to Lily) Great to see you. Charlie heads off.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Bye!... God, Violet, what was that about?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: That guy’s definitely in Professor Ryan’s class.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: That’s not possible -- he’s got a full-time job at Strategic Development Associates.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: He never got his coffee. The girls consider this significant detail.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why would he lie about something like that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: He’s lying. I find that... very attractive. Violet keeps looking intently in Charlie’s direction.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m going to stop cutting Professor Ryan’s class. CLOSE ON: A GIRL’S HAND WRITING COURSE NOTES--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet listening intently to Prof. Ryan, taking notes:

dialogues.speaker: PROF. RYAN
dialogues.text: It can be argued that Firbank was too little disciplined, too unserious in his unseriousness to create works of enduring value. But as a liberating influence on later writers such as Waugh, his importance should not be discounted. It’s not Firbank’s work itself but the idea of his work that so helped later writers --  73. as Thomas Love Peacock did in the previous century. While Prof. Ryan speaks Violet, perched high in the amphitheater, looks around. She catches a glimpse of some resembling Charlie, but in drab campus wear, slouched dow among friends, his face not visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Charlie-type hurries off with his friends as if obliv to Violet’s presence.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: So did you finish it?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Firbank just isn’t good..

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: I think he’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Charlie! Charlie! Charlie looks back; so do his friends.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: “Charlie?” Violet catches up to them.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Charlie! You are taking the course. Charlie looks awkward. FRIEND #2 laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: “Charlie?” Who's “Charlie?”

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Uh, Fred, what’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Fred?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: Uh-oh Fred, sounds like you’ve got some ‘splainin’ to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet and Charlie sit at a table.  74.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, you were lying.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE/FRED
dialogues.text: I wasn't lying. I was making it up.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Why were you making it up?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (looks around, whispers) If you were an eighth year Ed School student, would you advertise that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Eighth year, impressive. But your whole life was a lie -- dressing up in suits, buying people drinks?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, the suits -- were real. The drinks -- real. And I wasn’t just buying drinks for “people” -- they were for cute girls: there was a perfectly rational, logical, easily- explainable agenda.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: So it was a playboy or oper-a-tor move?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Of course. Transparently so.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I admire that -- drinks are expensive. But “Strategic Development” -- that was made up too?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I thought you said your cousin Jay was working in it.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What cousin Jay?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Cousin Jay in Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh. I don’t have any cousin in Philadelphia.  75.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You said your Cousin Jay in Philadelphia was working in Strategic Development.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I was just saying that to be friendly -- to make a kind of link... So your name’s Fred something?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yes, Fred something.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You really want to know? Violet nods. CHARLIE (CONT’D) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet with the others, studying but also talking.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Packenstacker?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigod, how crazy. He’s completely insane -- and I almost dated him.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: You can say that about a lot of guys.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I don’t think he’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Making up an entirely fictitious identity? That’s not crazy? It’s insane, psycho, weird...

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Violet's identity is made up. I don’t think she’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I am.  76.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: This is different. It’s pathetic... All that about “strategic development” he just made up -- don’t tell me that’s not weird.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I’m sure I’ve heard of “Strategic development” -- I think it’s something pretty important.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigod, Violet you’re not going to start going out with him? (watching her face) You’re not, are you?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, we had planned to go to the library...

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Not to the stacks, I hope. Violet nods.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Omigosh, do you realize how dangerous that is?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes. The stacks -- they’re dark and deserted. Anything could happen.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: It's true. With the study habits prevailing at Seven Oaks, your body might not be found until spring.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Promise you won’t go with him into the stacks. Please.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Okay, I’1l suggest the Randall Room.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Don’t suggest. Insist.  73 77.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: And please not at night.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a table in the elegant “Randall Reading Room.”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What are you reading? Fred shows her - a book of Walter Pater’s.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you chosen a topic for your final paper?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Uh, “The Decline of Decadence.”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You think decadence has declined?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Definitely. Big time. Major, Major decline.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: “How” or “in what ways?” Violet shrugs and shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Either.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Okay, take the flit movement in literature, or homosexuality: It’s gone completely downhill. Right down the tubes. He makes the sound: “Whchht.”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Before, homosexuality was something refined, hidden, sublimated, aspiring to the highest levels of creativity and expression and often  78. achieving them. Now it just seems to be a lot of muscle-bound morons running around in T-shirts. Violet looks a little shocked. FRED (CONT’D) It's pretty disillusioning. Violet pauses in thought for a long moment

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Are you gay?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Not especially but in another era, it might of had some appeal. Now, I just don’t see the point.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I think you might be romanticizing the past.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We'll never know. The past is... gone -- so we might as well romanticize it.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Hunh. You could be right.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I wanted to ask, how’s Lily?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Lily?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: She’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily walking looking thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just off campus a tall, thin fresh-faced California-type PAMPHLET GUY stands in the sidewalk as Lily approaches.

dialogues.speaker: PAMPHLET GUY
dialogues.text: Here, check it out A.L.A. No?.. Hello! Good afternoon!  79.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: PAMPHLET GUY
dialogues.text: Check it out. The A.L.A., have you heard of it? We have a meeting on Tuesday - you should come by. Lily politely takes the brochure he hands her.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What’s the “A.L.A."? She examines the text more closely.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: oh!

dialogues.speaker: PAMPHLET GUY
dialogues.text: Just join us -- come Tuesday. I think you'll really like it...

dialogues.speaker: A.L.A
dialogues.text: 76 INT. XAVIER’S HOUSE -- NIGHT 76 Xavier, with Lily that evening, puts the brochure down, h tone exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: So, a fellow was passing these out on the street and invited us to a meeting on Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: The “A.L.A.” -- oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I thought it was something related.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: You’re kidding. Lily, small voice, intimidated:

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: “The A.L.A.?” “The Anal Love Association?” What do we have to do with that? Lily looks down at the brochure again.  77 78 80.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven’t understood any of what we've talked about?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Talked about?...

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: The A.L.A. has nothing to do with us. Can’t you see that? Xavier sighs heavily and walks away, then returns.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The way we express love has meaning, it’s in the context of something beautiful. We're following our Creator’s teaching, aspiring to an ideal -- a beautiful one that brings an inexpressible closeness, not just to each other, but to-- He grabs the brochure.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For the A.L.A. and those like them, the love-act is just hedonistic pleasure-seeking, of a perverted nature -- there are words for people like that...! I can’t believe you'd think we had anything in common with them. We don’t, nothing, not an iota. Lily stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily is out the door and heading down the walkway, Xavier comes out after her.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Lily! Lily! Come back! Please, don’t be that way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, beyond Xavier’s neighborhood, on Lily as she walks

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: The Lone Star -- Saloon & Dance Hall  79 80 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on: feet during a line dance, lots of boots and hea footwear -- just a couple pairs of light “Repetto” slippe amidst all the clomping. A wider view -- Violet, Rose, Heather, Jimbo, Fred amidst more “Western” dancers: Jimbo keen on a reserved Rose, Violet with Fred. Across the roo Lily enters looking sad. From the sidelines she watches t dancers. After a bit, the others notice her, Violet wavin for her to join them. Lily shakes her head and dodges the looks. Finally, Violet breaks away from the line.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Omigosh, Lily, are you okay? Lily shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You don’t want to talk about it? Lily, still silent, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is clustered at the far end of the bar as a les dance-able, sad and poignant Western ballad plays.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: But... I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You don’t understand what?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: What is ‘non-procreative love- making?’

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, it could be a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah -- but in this case?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We don’t have to talk about this--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, I don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Could somebody just explain to me what this is all about?  82.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, what it is is...uh--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Because Cathars don’t believe in procreative sex, they don’t have intercourse the usual way.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: The usual way? A brief, awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You don’t have to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. Yes, the normal way, from the front -- where you can have procreation -- not from the other side... where you can’t. A light goes on in Jimbo’s head.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: The other side... That’s their religion?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Not exactly but that’s the direction their beliefs head in -- when they want to express love, that’s what they do.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: And you liked that?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It got pretty uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: So, it started out comfortable and got uncomfortable later?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Man! Do we have to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: How horrible. You poor girl.  81 82 83

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: That’s terrible. What he obliged Lily to do.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: You know, some people like that.
81 Frank with Thor and others from the D.U. stand with brews watching the dancers and looking clueless. Frank catches sight of Violet and walks toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank comes up behind Violet.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Violet. Can we talk? Violet turns -- they all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group vacates a booth and Violet and Frank slip in. at the bar, looks critically in their direction. For Frank is tongue-tied, mostly looking down.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You must be pretty mad at me.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You’re not? Violet shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: But it was so terrible, how everything happened -- your walking in on us. Violet shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s easier that way. 82 83 Rose, a time  84. Frank looks down and goes silent.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That bitch! He looks down again. Violet waits for elaboration but the is none.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it. What a bitch. That bitch!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Priss?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Of course Priss! What a bitch. Oh, man... That whole thing -- (imita tes Priss) “I'm so stressed, sad, depressed. I’m so tired. ‘I’m fatigued.’” That's what she said. She couldn’t sleep or something. She was so depressed she had to get everything her own way-- (mimicking her) "I’m so stressed -- frantic!" Man! What. A. Bitch!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Priss dumped you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No. It was mutual. Frank goes silent again, then remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, I have a question, do you remember that bean ball I left in your room? Violet nods.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you still have it?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you think I could get it back? I lost the other one and with everything that's happened, I'd really like to have it.  84 85 86 85.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Nothing like some bean ball after a break up!

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Yeah. God you’re smart. You always get it. Whatever I say, you understand. Man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet walks back to the dance floor and rejoins the danc Fred and Lily already seem uncomfortably close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thor, holding a brewski, approaches Heather.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Hey, Heather.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: (with a flirting lilt) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Hey. Thor smiles and makes a fist, lightly touching it to Heather’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing group continues to dance, Violet somewhat isolated. The flirting and closeness between Fred and Lil becomes difficult for her to bear. Violet abruptly leaves line and heads for the door. Fred, seeing her go, stops.  87 89 90 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet stalks out and heads at a fast pace towards the university. Fred comes out and catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Violet, what’s wrong? She won't say anything and just keeps walking. FRED (CONT’D) Violet, please, stop!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry... Lily is lovely. I can understand why you would be attracted to her. Now she’s free. Go. I understand. Violet turns and runs off; Fred remains looking after her Fade to black.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: Roman Holidays OMINOUS, SENTENTIOUS MUSIC SUCH AS ‘THUS SPAKE ZARATHUSTR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late afternoon Roman Holidays party scene at the D.U. -- toga, towel and sheet-clad “Romans” booze it up while bad rock blares. The courtyard has been set up as a coliseum an inebriated, semi-dressed gladiator with a rubber sword staggers forward and, spouting idiot Latin, charges a Gol Lab disguised as a lion:

dialogues.speaker: GLADIATOR
dialogues.text: Aunque utque! Latin! Et... cetera! Charging, the Gladiator falls on his face before reaching dog who licks his face.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is what comes from not teaching Latin in the schools!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls (minus Lily), elegantly dressed in plausibly Ro style, watch. Violet, though still sad, comments indulgen

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yah, it’s moronic and boorish, but also kind of fun, don’t you think?  91 92 93 94 87.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No. They look back as a roar rises from the D.U. crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chariot race has begun, predominantly razor scooters an skate boards. As the course extends outside the courtyard the “lion” takes off.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The art and thought of the classical age were the glory of civilization. These are nothing but moronic fraternity high jinx -- not improving or uplifting in the least. There are some smash-ups as the race descends into a spectacle of drunkenness and hopeless chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Rose looks faint and gasps, placing her hand ove her face.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh no -- what’s that... stench?! Rose gags as if about to wretch. From the girls’ right co another roar; they turn to see:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horde of “barbarians” charges from Doar Dorm with animalistic shouts and calls, their dress and demeanor fi and frightening, like something out of BRAVEHEART though college wear. The barbarians rush the short distance to t DU grounds. Immediately a full melee breaks out.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I suppose this is what happens when decadence rots society from within--

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: And from with out.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: And not the interesting decadence of former times but the moronic kind you get today. She nods toward the on-going melee.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Such a society is, I fear, destined to fail and be overrun. Rose, hands over her nose, winces from the barbarian smel

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Maybe that’s good. They watch more melee as the scene fades, the fighting so and wails of wounded Romans continuing over BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP ON GRAPHIC
dialogues.text: “Complainer” Headline: FRATERNITIES BANNED!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rick strides with his posse.

dialogues.speaker: RICK
dialogues.text: Finally! It’s about time those cesspools were drained!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A subdued Thor, Frank and their D.U. brothers bring out furniture including a strange hippie beanbag armchair whi could be violet, lavender, mauve or purple in color.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: What color would you say that chair is?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That's a chair? I have no idea. INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- DAY 96 Rose and Heather study; Violet fretfully looks over Lily’ well-made bed and ordered desk.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Guys have their preferences.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You’re just going to accept that? You’re not going to do anything?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to be done. Fred must know his own mind.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Oh really? I seriously doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Come on, Lily’s got that slender, delicately swelling, blossoming beauty no man can resist.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Okay, you're probably right.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Poor Lily. Think of all Xavier put her through. A pause for thought.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He just used her body -- and not even the right side.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Have you ever noticed that good and moral people tend to have large posteriors. Not everyone, by any means -- and I know it's not logical -- but it does seem to me true.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The genetic link between morality and large posteriors? Yes, I think that’s well known.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: You and Violet have that build -- it’s nice, you’re still very attractive -- but are also sensible and moralistic. I don’t. I have narrow hips, but also no very strong principles. There’s a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes? Violet goes to the door, glancing through the peephole be opening it.  90.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, hi. Frank strolls in.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hi, Heather -- wow. (to Lily) I guess you guys all heard -- the university is closing all the Roman- letter houses.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- it’s terrible. This year’s Roman Holidays did seem like the end of civilization -- but even when civilization ends, people are going to need a place to stay.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Man, it’s bad. It’s that bastard from the Complainer. Apparently someone from the administration has been reading it -- hard to believe. Bastard! Listen, we were wondering, if you thought it’d be okay if we stayed at the Suicide Center until we find somewhere else to go? Violet looks to the others.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Okay, sure -- that sounds like a good stopgap measure.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thank you, thank you.... There was, uh, one more thing -- you remember that bean ball we talked about?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Do you think I could pick that up? After everything that's happened, I could really use it right now.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. Violet goes to find it, Frank following. As she opens the box, he notices the note in his handwriting.  91.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: That note.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh. One gets so few things written by hand anymore, I guess I kept it...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Hunh. Frank picks up the note and reads it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Out for brewskies - back in a Gif" [hard “g”]. What’s a “Gif?” The scooter, like a Vespa, right?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: That’s what I thought.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I was thinking of getting one. Frank looks to Heather with appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You must have meant “jiff.” “Back in a jiff” and then misspelled it, or spelled it in a non-standard way.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Not a good speller. Frank throws the bean ball up in the air and catches it rather skillfully.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks! You’re great. Priss was such a bitch... Damn! Damn! (leaving) Hey, Heather -- Bye. (to Rose) Bye.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Bye. Violet steps out in the hall with Frank who corners her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Wow, Heather is really cute. She’s like, really attractive. Is she, uh, going out with anyone?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I think there might be something between her and Thor.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thor! Damn. Heather and Thor? Damn. Damn!

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: The Ed School -- “Robertson Hall”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose walks with Violet who’s obviously quite upset and overwrought.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I can’t bear this tension with Lily. It’s terrible to have the group divided this way. Rose looks up and guides Violet away from the path alongs Robertson Hall.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Better not next to Robertson.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear? Suicidal Ed School students have been going up to the roof and throwing themselves off.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: But, it’s only two stories--

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes, I know, it’s terrible -- not high enough to kill but high enough to maim, and particularly dangerous for anyone below. They head down the central path -- a safe distance away.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’ve got to forget about Fred.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: But you really liked him.  93.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: This whole thing of a person meeting someone else first: it’s so arbitrary, it’s terrible and cruel - She looks to Rose for support but only gets a blank look.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- especially when that selection by “priority” is the opposite of how things ought to be.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I have to say, I was wrong about Fred. I thought he was a playboy or oper-a-tor type. In fact, he’s just another guy rendered helpless by the attentions of a pretty girl. They are interrupted by a commotion, shouts, from nearby Robertson Hall and a young woman following a young man ac its roof.

dialogues.speaker: ED SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Cary! Cary! No! Don’t! I love you! The young man looks over the balustrade and as the girl approaches, jumps -- out of frame. Close on Rose and Viol watching: the sound of a slight “thud” in the distance, t a sharp squeal of pain.

dialogues.speaker: ED SCHOOL GUY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Owwwww! Owwwwww!

dialogues.speaker: ED SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Why did you do that? Carry, I love you! Rose and Violet resume walking.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Isn’t the Ed School essentially a teachers’ college?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What concerns me is, if they can’t even destroy themselves, how are they going to teach America’s Youth?

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: Thor 97 INT. GIRLS’ ROOM -- NIGHT 97 It's quiet, the lights off: Violet, Rose and Heather in t bunks.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I’m really worried about Thor... It’s hard for us to imagine how upsetting it is not knowing what the colors are.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: In fact it’s impossible for me to imagine.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: When Thor sees a rainbow -- it’s only so much gibberish to him. There was one this afternoon: omigosh he took it hard. Recently there was a parade in the city where the marchers carried rainbow- colored flags and banners --- Thor was so upset: he said he’d no idea what it meant --

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What kind of retard is he?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: See, that’s the conclusion people immediately jump to.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Well, it’s somewhat understandable.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Not if you knew the full story.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: What’s the full story?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: You know how parents love bragging about how precocious their children are? Thor’s parents had become precocity-addicts: constantly needing an ever-greater precocity “fix.” When he should have entered kindergarten, they instead pushed him into First Grade. “Oh, Thor skipped a grade,” they could tell their friends, most of whom were terrible precocity-addicts too.  95.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (suddenly alarmed) What’s this all about?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: What Thor’s parents failed to consider was the enormously important academic work done in nursery school -- key being the study of colors, which in Thor’s case were -- a complete blank. Can you imagine?... I don’t want to be too critical of Thor’s parents. I suppose they just assumed that colors are the sort of knowledge people pick up along the way -- like, for example not stepping on sidewalk cracks. There’s an odd sound.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (whispers) I think Rose’s sleeping. A silence, except for the sound of Rose’s breathing.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Am I boring?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, not at all. When you’ve problems yourself, it’s great to hear someone else’s truly idiotic ones. Please go on. A shocked pause.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: When you said that about depressed people being mean, you weren’t joking.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry -- you're right. Please go on.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. You know how I am. Please continue. On Heather’s face as she struggles with her resentment.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Thor decided he absolutely had to learn all the colors, both primary and mixed. He’s been hitting the books really hard and thought he had finally mastered them. Then in town today he said “that traffic light’s blue.” I had to say, no, it’s green. He was really upset. He'd been so sure it was blue.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The traffic lights in town are sort of blue.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: This was a green light --“cross at the green, not in-between.”

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yah, we call them “green” but they’re actually more bluish.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: “Bluish” but still green.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, they can be blue. I know it sounds strange but--

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Huhn. I don’t know about that. Frankly, it’s hard to believe. Anyway, we continued walking and a naval officer passed us. Thor blurted out, a bit aggressively, “his uniform’s black.” I had to correct him. Navy uniforms are blue, “navy blue” -- that’s why they're called that way. Omigosh, he was upset! It was as if he were going to cry. Rose awakes, a little alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You know, actually, that’s true: navy uniforms are black.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: They're navy blue. That’s the color’s name.  97.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, by mistake the Navy received a huge shipment of fabric that was black, not blue. So as not to waste it they decided to sew gold braid on and use it -- and found that everyone assumed it was blue, navy blue, when it was in fact black.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Still? Navy uniforms are still black?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes -- I believe so. In the dark Heather gets out of bed and starts looking ar for her clothes and dressing.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I’ve got to tell Thor! There’s no telling what he might do! The door opens and someone enters from outside. HEATHER (CONT’D) Who’s that?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It’s me.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Lily.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We were worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet, Rose, Heather and other volunteers pack bars of t “wonder” soap in oval cardboard packets. Behind them displaced DU members, sleeping bags lying around, lounge, play with bean balls, etc.  98.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: It's getting to look like a homeless shelter in here.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: These guys are not really “homeless” -- they lost their fraternity house. It’d be better to call them “house-less.”

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Okay. It’s getting to look like a house-less shelter then. Violet turns to some of the D.U. refugees.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Hey, could you guys help?! Frank and another approach. (Thor, in the background, cli back in his sleeping bag, depressed and dejected.)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Sure, what’s up?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: We need help packing this soap which we’ll then distribute to Doar Dorm residents.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What would you say are the most effective means to fight depression? Frank is completely stumped. His D.U. brothers listen in, making faces.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe some of your D.U. brothers have an idea. The D.U. guys think.

dialogues.speaker: DU GUY
dialogues.text: Uh, beer?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: No -- beer’s a downer. Cocktails -- hard liquor, “spirits” -- is what really gives you a lift.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It's interesting what you say. My Cousin Jay’s a medical officer in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philadelphia: he says alcoholism -- by which I mean chronic, excessive consumption of alcohol -- is the primary self-administered treatment for depression.

dialogues.speaker: DU GUY
dialogues.text: Cool.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No. Ultimately it leaves you much worse off than before.

dialogues.speaker: DU GUY
dialogues.text: Oh no, not me. I just boot, and then feel fine.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: By “boot,” do you mean “vomit?”

dialogues.speaker: DU GUY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, none of the effective anti- suicide treatments involve vomiting. D.U. guy thinks.

dialogues.speaker: DU GUY
dialogues.text: Hunh.... a treatment for depression that doesn’t involve vomiting...

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Uh -- hygiene?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Exactly. It’s very important. That's why we have such hope in the wonder bar. Do you know its scent? They shake their heads. Violet cups in the palms of her hands and offers it up to them. They inhale deeply -- and are (somewhat) transported.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DU_ GUY
dialogues.text: It’s guu--uud.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Transformative, we think.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: This is so exciting. -- it’s really great, isn’t it.  100 100. On Rose’s skeptical visage as she listens: HEATHER (CONT’D) I can just see those guys opening the packages, taking out the soap, smelling it and then excitedly going to wash themselves. For them finally to be clean, free from that horrible acrid smell, how different the world might look to them.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. Violet, looking around, notices Thor lying prostrate in h sleeping bag, his head buried in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s wrong with Thor?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don’t know -- he asked me about the weather. When I told him it looked “very gray,” he looked around -- and seemed really upset. Thor lies with his head buried under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I better go to him. Heather heads toward where Thor is.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Thor’s gotten so worked up over this color business. My God, it’s weird! Didn’t we all learn that stuff in kindergarten?! INT. GIRLS’ ROOM/HALL -- NIGHT 100 Violet studies at her desk, then gets up as if taking a break. As she walks there’s a distinct clack sound. She's wearing tap shoes, walking delicately so as not to make t much noise. But the “clacks” are still pretty notable. Sh heads down the hall toward the bathroom -- suddenly a hal door swings open and MAD MADGE leans out.

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE
dialogues.text: What do you think you’re doing?!

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Going to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE
dialogues.text: Making a racket like that?  101.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, did I disturb you?

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE
dialogues.text: What do you think? Why are you wearing tap shoes -- are you out of your mind?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes, I think that’s clear. Quite a few others stick their heads out.

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m so sick of that.

dialogues.speaker: POSITIVE POLLY
dialogues.text: Oh, really? I think it’s cute. Madge gives Polly a dirty look.

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE
dialogues.text: Since you won’t be treating us to one of your hilariously incompetent tap routines, why don’t you take those things off?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, we’ll do the routine... Rose! Violet hurries back toward the room, no longer trying to soften her clacks:

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Madge wants to see the routine!

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE
dialogues.text: No -- Rose retreats within the room to put the music on.

dialogues.speaker: MAD MADGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --I don’t want to see your absurd routine -- I asked you to take those things off!

dialogues.speaker: POSITIVE POLLY
dialogues.text: Please Madge, please, we need a break--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Just briefly, please, it’s helpful to have an audience-- Rose, the music.

dialogues.speaker: MADGE
dialogues.text: I’m going to report you!  101 102. “Things Are Looking Up” blasts from the stereo. Violet begins her dance down the hall -- it’s joyous and amazing Rose appears, with taps on, and joins in. Mad Madge slams her door. As Violet and Rose tap up and down the hall and stairs, their hall mates enjoy the spectacle. INT. MR. BLACK’S SEMINAR - DAY 101 The seminar classroom of the wise and elegant CHARLES BLA the students respond to one of his questions.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACK
dialogues.text: Susanne?

dialogues.speaker: COED
dialogues.text: For me it'd be, Madame Curie, Simone de Beauvoir and, Margaret Sanger.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACK
dialogues.text: Good. Violet?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I would say: Richard Straus, Roderick Charleston and... Chubbert Checker.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACK
dialogues.text: (pronouncing) “Rickard” Straus, the composer?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes -- that was one of his posts.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACK
dialogues.text: I’m not familiar with the others -- could you tell us who they are and what links them?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. Violet swivels slightly to include the other students, speaking slowly for their benefit.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Each one of these men started an international dance craze -- “Rickard” Straus, the Waltz; Roderick Charleston, the Charleston, and Chubbert Checker, better known as “Chubby”, the dance we know as the Twist.  103 103.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACK
dialogues.text: (smiling) Why do you consider starting a dance craze so important?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (surprised) Dance crazes enhance and elevate the human experience, bringing together millions of people ina joyous celebration of our God-given faculties and passing these delightful modes of physical expression down through the generations -- though not so much any more. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: MR. BLACK
dialogues.text: I thought -- well, I guess I assumed that “the Charleston” was named after the city of Charleston, South Carolina. Violet maintains a studied and level expression.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No... Though that misconception is quite widely held. It was Roderick Charleston. Usually behind some great creative phenomenon is a person, not a town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freak and Violet practice a song and dance version of “Th are Looking Up,” the chorus dancing behind:

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: (singing) Oh things are looking up, Since love looked up at me! Priss pops into the room and stands by observing. Debbie, the chorus, notices Priss and stops, as do others.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Priss!

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Hi Debs.

dialogues.speaker: FREAK
dialogues.text: Break! Freak stalks off; Priss approaches Violet hesitantly.  104.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Violet, I am so sorry... You must hate me. I know what I did was wrong -- but, if things ended so easily between you and Frank, isn’t it best that they did so? Isn’t it better to break with someone so unreliable?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: What I’m saying is, I know now I should never have gotten involved with anyone. I was still on the rebound from Josh. But, inadvertently, I did something that you must acknowledge as positive. Aren’t you much better off being rid of a... numbskull like that?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Priss, come on -- don’t apologize to her! Of course what you did was right.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: I know it sounds crazy, but if I did help you disentangle from Frank, isn’t that for the best? Frank was unworthy of you, Violet -- you must know that. Let’s be honest, he’s an idiot, a moron. How would it have been, your whole life attached to a dope like that?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Priss? Priss turns. Frank, with some DU guys behind him, stands with a crushed look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How can you say something like that, Priss? I’m not a... moron. I... loved you.

dialogues.speaker: PRISS
dialogues.text: Well that wasn’t very bright of you, was it? I was clearly on the rebound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on Lily eating, widen on the whole group having breakfast. Violet seems somewhat sad, Heather a bit high.  105.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: This is so exciting -- when should we go over there?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I don’t think there’s any rush.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: No, I'd like to go as soon as possible. Doar Dorm has the university’s highest fatality rate, as well as the worst hygiene. This could really change things.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: The highest suicide rate?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, the highest fatality rate -- it’s not certain what percentage were intentional and how many just due to a temporary unawareness of gravity’s laws.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: I can just see those guys getting the little gold packages, opening them and finding the terrifically good-smelling soap inside. Despite their habitual reticence toward hygiene, the wonderful scent and cute packaging should prove irresistible. And, once clean, they’1l start to see the world with new eyes. The change could be dramatic. Doar Dorm could soon become -- “Dior Dorm.”

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I doubt that, to be perfectly, absolutely honest.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No, I love the idea -- Dior Dorm. I adore optimism, even when completely absurd, perhaps especially then.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Great! Ready? Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls walk in the direction of Doar Dorm, Heather slightly ahead.  106 106.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Let’s hurry. She starts to jog -- Violet catches up to her.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Let’s not let our hopes up get too high, Heather.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: No, you said yourself -- the Wonder Bar is transformative. Fred, walking the other way, spots them.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Hey, Violet! Fred falls in with them. FRED (CONT’D) Hi. Where are you going? Violet is a little nervous and tongue-tied.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Doar Dorm.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Fred! Hi! Lily runs up to fall in by Fred just as they turn the cor and see: Outside Doar Dorm and pouring out of its doors D Dorm guys and a few Doar Dorm “women” throw small oval di back and forth in an enormous frisbee-like free for all. of the discs falls at Violet’s feet: it’s the oval packag they used for the Wonder Bar, never opened. The girls loo to each other, appalled. Two guys jump for the same disc, bashing into each other, one dropping like a stone as if dead.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Omigod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group walks back from Doar Dorm, Heather upset.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I guess it wasn’t realistic to expect Doar Dorm to turn into “Dior Dorm” overnight.  107.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: They wouldn’t even open them: they said without the soap, the discs wouldn’t fly properly. Rose turns to Fred.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Are you coming Friday? Violet is launching her dance craze at the Lone Star. Fred's impressed.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Really? That’s great. What’s the dance?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: The “Sambola” -- the Devil’s Dance.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Cool. (to Lily) We'll go, right?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Yes, I’d like to but I have several papers to finish. But I’d like to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet and Rose beginning their evening ablutions.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I’m beginning to learn things about myself. I’m actually a really poor judge of character--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: No-—

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No, I am. A terrible excess of opinion distorts my judgement. I was completely wrong about him, he’s not a playboy or oper-a-tor type at all. He’s a loser.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I’m the biggest loser of anyone... First semester, "Forget Frank." Second semester, "Forget Fred."

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Have you forgotten him?  109 108. Violet, eyes watering, shakes her head “no.”

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t think you should give up on him. Rose spits the toothpaste into the sink.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One thought reassures me: Our stupidity must be part of God’s Divine Plan. He must have made us stupid for a reason.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Because He wants us to have kids? “Be fruitful and multiply.”

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Yes. Probably.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: The Lone Star -- Debut of the “Samboloa” Dance Craze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Violet, sharply dressed, completes a music check with the Manager GUS near the dance area, then goes to Rose at the where cocktails have just been served. Violet gives a worried look around the sparsely populated bar.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It’s great! Thanks, Gus. (to Rose) I don’t see how we’re going to start a dance craze if no guys show up.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Most guys aren’t very good at the dance craze thing anyway.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yeah, but still... Heather enters, out of breath, dressed for the dance but otherwise preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Very good news! I was just at my procrastination seminar and the two guys from Doar Dorm -- had showered. It was pretty clear they’d used soap -- Omigosh, what a  109. difference! It seems they’d been throwing the packages so energetically a soap bar fell out -- the unfamiliar, ivory-like object intrigued them. One thing led to another and -- well, it was just as you said. Isn’t that great? Violet and Rose nod. Violet takes a few steps, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh look, here’s Jimbo.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: Where is everybody?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: This is pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily and Fred study and talk at one of the bar’s corner booths. Fred checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Aren't we going to be late for Violet’s dance craze?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You want to go to that?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You’re kidding.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: No. I love dance crazes.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Gosh, you’re strange...

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Aren’t we already late?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No, it’s later on, like 10 I think... I have to confess I’ve started losing patience with Violet. Depression calls for serious treatment -- medication, psycho-pharmaceuticals, talk therapy--  110.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: But are those approaches really so effective? Despite all the medication and therapy, Ed School students are still throwing themselves off Robertson Hall. Violet’s ideas might seem a little off-beat--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: A little off-beat! Omigod. I don’t know how much you know about Violet but there’s some pretty weird stuff. “Violet,” “Violet Wister” is not even her real name.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: It isn’t?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: No. It’s “Emily Tweeter.” Apparently when she was eleven years old she went completely crazy and has had several relapses since, so it’s a little worrisome to have her counsel nearly suicidal individuals-

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: “Emily Tweeter” -- in First Grade I had an enormous crush on a girl with that name.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You remember that?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was pretty huge, Dr. Zhivago stuff. Any idea or even mention of her filled me with emotion. Admittedly I had a very strange perspective on the world then; I don’t think my brain was fully formed or functioning properly -- everything was a bit of a dream. Then a bizarre thing happened. I was torn about whether to shout my passion from the roof tops or keep it secret. Ina sort of compromise I wrote Emily’s name, in crayon, on a scrap of paper, then carefully hid it in my  111. bookcase where no one else could possibly find it. So, my secret was expressed but, ostensibly, safe -- I'd no idea of the weird and inexplicable events that would follow. Lily looks a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Two years afterwards I was walking up the street a couple of blocks from my house when I spotted a slip of paper lying, face up, on the sidewalk near someone’s trash -- the name “Emily Tweeter” written on it in crayon in my own child-like handwriting. He stares into Lily’s eyes with an expression of total bafflement and candor. FRED (CONT’D) It was completely, utterly weird. How could my secret, so well hidden, come to land on the sidewalk of Henderson Drive? Lily tries to help him.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Could, uh--

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: No. I’ve thought long and hard about it -- there’s no rational explanation. This was my first encounter with the bizarre and inexplicable. When I later learned about the Bermuda Triangle and other such mysterious phenomena, I knew it was probably all true as I'd had this early brush with the uncanny. From a very young age it became clear to me that rationalism cannot explain life’s deepest mysteries.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: And you think this girl was Violet?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I have to say I didn’t recognize her. She was very young then. Do you have any idea if Violet might  111 112. have attended Willamette Montessori?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: In Portland? Fred nods. The barman arrives with a tray of cocktails -- much to their surprise.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We didn’t order these.

dialogues.speaker: BARMAN
dialogues.text: Compliments of the guy at the bar. Lily and Fred look toward the bar -- Xavier, wearing a su nods to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly after, Xavier is with them in the booth.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: +..It was so brutal how it ended between us. I know I was too angry and a bit, crazy but I thought what we had was stronger than that. That you would not just walk away after one disagreement. With all we had been through, couldn’t you have just forgiven me... Lily says nothing for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: It wasn’t just that...

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Oh, you mean, my Cathar beliefs? Lily nods. Xavier is a little emotional.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, I am no longer a Cathar.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: How’s that possible?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: It's been very difficult.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: You’ve entirely dropped your adherence to the Cathar faith?

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Yes. I have.  112 113 113.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Good. Normally I'd be reluctant to comment on anyone’s religion...

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I guess I’m a bit of a bigot -- I could never take seriously a religion that worships on Tuesdays. All the major religions require worship on the weekend -- Friday, Saturday or Sunday. I find it really laudatory that people should sacrifice their weekend time to Worship God... He checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: XAVIER
dialogues.text: Having sabbath on Tuesday always seemed very bizarre to me. It is not right.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We'd better get to the Lone Star--

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Why are you so concerned about that?

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: It’s not as if international dance crazes start every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fred, Lily and Xavier hurry down the sidewalk -- semi- Jogging.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: We better hurry. They pick up the pace. Lily seems a little less keen on getting to their destination --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three approach the Lone Star, just as Rose, Heather, Violet and Jimbo come out looking downcast.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: What’s wrong?  114 115 114.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Another fiasco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four are in bed in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Sometimes our struggle reminds me of the Myth of Sisyphus.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: The myth about the guy who pushes an enormous rock up a hill, only to have it keep rolling back down again.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. What a knucklehead. The important thing to remember is that he was mythical -- he never really existed.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Violet, did you spend any part of your education at a school called Willamette Montessori?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: In Oregon? Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thor, Jimbo, and the girls huddled inside on a drab day; glance at Fred who speaks on his phone on the Coffee Cottage’s porch -- a drizzle falls outside.

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Would you say that today is “very gray?” Jimbo looks around.

dialogues.speaker: JIMBO
dialogues.text: I'd say so. Maybe “blue-gray.” Thor looks around, trying to factor this in. Fred finishe the call and comes in.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, her name wasn’t “Emily Tweeter” but “Lucy Wurlitzer.” I  115. know they're not very similar: I’m beginning to realize that the human memory is not the foolproof instrument we sometimes imagine. What’s worse it seems everyone knew all about my obsession, including my parents and siblings -- precisely those from whom I most wanted it kept.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: So from your earliest years you were already a playboy or oper-a- tor type.

dialogues.speaker: FRED
dialogues.text: Yes. I suppose that’s why secrecy seemed so desirable.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Violet, can I talk to you? Lily, having silently followed all this, stands and nods Violet, who gets up too. As they walk to the coffee count Lily whispers to her confidentially.

dialogues.speaker: LILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s the plural of doufus?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Doufi.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Not doufuses?

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You can say either: “doufi” respects the Latin root and so is preferred. “Doufuses” is also correct, although a bit inelegant.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: You’ve thought a lot about this.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Yes. I’ve had to.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I like Fred -- he’s a nice guy and I can see why you like him... Any mass of people, such as you might find in a large university or high school, divides into many different  116 117 118 119 116. groups. Normally there’s a “cool crowd,” and then variously less cool crowds. When I first met you and Rose, I thought you were the “cool crowd” -- and, in many ways, you are. I find your perfume and fashion sense excellent.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: But...there’s a reason, I think, why you are so strongly attracted to doufi. And it’s not an accident. How different groups divide up... While Lily speaks Violet notices something.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thor! No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn in time to see Thor run into the street followe Heather. The sun is out and its rays, bouncing off the da clouds still hanging in the sky, create an exquisite ligh effect. Everyone follows them into the street. In the distance a rainbow has formed -- this is what panicked Heather. Thor runs hell for leather toward the beautiful arc, Heather after him.

dialogues.speaker: HEATHER
dialogues.text: Thor! No! Stop! Please, stop! TIGHT ON: Thor’s face as he runs, torn with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: He’s headed for Robertson Hall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thor disappears inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thor runs up the stairs, Heather behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thor runs toward the balustrade, Heather comes up from th stairs, almost too winded to call:
At the balustrade Thor stops for a moment and gazes at th rainbow in its terrifying splendor. He points first to th topmost band of color, then each succeeding one:

dialogues.speaker: THOR
dialogues.text: Red!... Orange! Yellow!... Green! Blue! Indigo! Violet!... Hallelujah, Lord God, thank you! Heather reaches him and they embrace, gazing at the rainb together, Thor’s face wet with tears of joy. THOR (CONT’D) Education! We can learn the subjects we set out to master, no matter how hard or impossible they may seem. Thank you! Thank you -- I wasn't sure I was going to make it! Together they look to the rainbow horizon. Thor studies a nods his head again toward it, proud of his new competenc

dialogues.speaker: THOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Magenta... Pink... Mauve...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose and Violet, thoughtful, study together on benches.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I miss my nice American friend.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: No, you're mistaken.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: Oh come on, you go to London for four weeks--

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Six.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: It’s very dangerous, parents letting their children travel. They see them off at the airport and don’t know what they’1ll be getting back. Rose reflects on this.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what you’re referring to.  118.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: You’re not from London.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I’m from London. I was there, and now I’m here. I’m “from” London.

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
dialogues.text: I just miss my nice American friend.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Nice. (caricatures a nasal American accent) “Nice. Nice. Fine. ‘Fine.’” (reverts to type) Those are not adjectives I like to use. God gave us abilities -- he requires that we use them: “Good. Better. Best.” “Excelsior! Higher!” Only excellence can glorify the Lord. Vulgarity is, in essence, blasphemous.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: In the Matter of the Doufi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lily and Violet come down a path, both in frilly “Damsels costumes.

dialogues.speaker: LILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry what I was saying before - - of course you’re not irretrievably linked to the doufi or even that such distinctions are valid--

dialogues.speaker: VIOLET
